title: Tedros Adhanom
summary: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus (Tigrinya: ቴዎድሮስ አድሓኖም ገብረኢየሱስ; born 3 March 1965[1]) is an Ethiopian[1] biologist, public health researcher, and official[2] who has been Director-General of the World Health Organization since 2017.[3][4] Tedros is the first African in the role,[5] and was endorsed by the African Union.[6] He played a role in the response to both the Ebola outbreak and the COVID-19 pandemic.
